comments.html: I remember a similar issue with the server-side email filtering language SIEVE: in its early days, it used 2000/tcp by default, but later did move to 4190/tcp. 2000/tcp is still in use by legacy configurations, but later became assigned to Cisco's Skinny protocol. As a result, an ASA in place may accept the connection (client thinks "server accepts the tcp connection), the ASA doesn't read skinny protocol packets and hence closes the connection (clients thinks "server closed connection"). Of course, the SIEVE server doesn't ever see an incoming connection from that client - and so one can easily spend days debugging this.
comments.name: Anders

comments.html:
My one experience with 'fix'ups was on a Cisco ASA doing remote user vpn.. When I installed it I never disabled the default inspection stuff (What harm could they do?).

Much later, after what should have been an uneventful update on some windows servers, no one could access email (MAPI) over the vpn. Turns out the update changed a default rpc port or something causing the ASA to think the traffic was malformed skinny packets, and drop it.
